summary: A group of German POWs are forced to dig up millions of land mines with their bare hands.

reviews.content: Touching and heart breaking story, based on real historic events.

I've watched a lot of war movies, not for the action, but to be reminded of atrocities and not all, but a lot of needless shedding of blood. This one, however is one of the most devastating war films I've ever watched. The war was actually already over, but the Danish military made their German POW's clear their beaches of land mines. The film shows a small group of German soldiers made up of mostly teenagers who weren't brainwashed by fascism and Nazism, but just happened to have their number called. Many of them died not directly by the enemy, but by bombs planted by their own country that they were made to diffuse. A devastating portrait of the hatred war inflicts on even those we think of as the "good guys" turning just as bad as those we consider the "bad guys". Revenge doesn't heal. Only forgiveness. It may be a long, and arduous process, but letting your enemy blow themselves up in the postscript of the war didn't make anyone feel better. Masterpiece of a film, and study of humanity.

Such a master piece. Shows how the war made people each other's villains. Force you to remember that no matter the side you're on, there's innocent folks paying the price. Great watch and I can't recommend it enough
Amazing movie. Great acting, simple yet very effective plot, constant sense of foreboding and danger. Germans really know how to make these sorts of war films.

This is not a war movie; it's, in its own way, a delicate tale about human connections and what war can do to people. The main characters are literally children who just want to go home and see their parents again, and instead, they're forced to embark on something very similar to a suicide mission, to pay for something they had no part in. Most of the protagonists were probably like 11 when the war started.

 "Land of mine" truly shows that there's nothing beautiful in war. Honor, courage, sacrifice, all these things don't matter anymore when it all ends and we're left with nothing but ruins and a broken people. It manages to show the multiple points of view of a very complicated situation, and it avoids any kind of glorification of war. I can guarantee that after seeing "Land of Mine you won't ever see other war movies the same way again, because most of them will seem slightly cartoonish and naive at times. 

This is a must-see, no doubt about it, but please be aware of the fact that it's really hard to watch. This is not something I would watch in class. If you have anxiety problems, or even just if you're a very sensitive person, it can get really hard to sit through some scenes. There's two in particular that I haven't stopped thinking about for days (the scene set at night with the soldiers was really bad. I had to get up and take a deep breath when I watched the movie).

The acting is really good, especially considering the fact that most actors are pretty young. I think this was one of Louis Hoffman's first roles, for example. You might know him from "Dark" on Netflix. He play Sebastian. I didn't recognize the actor playing Ernst but he was excellent too. And the Danish officer was just fantastic!

This is one of the most beautiful movies I've seen in the past year, but it's not a fun, light watch. It's not even a war movie. It's a story of love, loss, hate and understanding. It deserves to be appreciated more.
Good Movie, a Bit low budget

It is difficult to believe that in just one hundred minutes, so much could be discussed and developed. The human, deeply emotional but by no means overdone or sentimental message transcends the specifics - the themes of post-war hate, forgiveness, justice are applicable to any conflict anywhere in the world.

The basis for the film is a real series of events. After the war, the British, the Danish, and the German authorities agree on using POWs to clear minefields, tens of thousands of mines…

We are firmly outside the Geneva Convention here… as that agreement resulted in barely ‘trained' teenage prisoners being sent to the coastline, where more than forty thousand mines were to be defused and removed by them. Essentially, a war crime was committed, full stop.

But this raises complex questions, and the film, with its deeply affecting human story manages to raise them beautifully: where is the line between a desire for vengeance and justice? What is individual vs collective responsibility after a war, especially as we have here young boys who were conscripted by Hitler in the last months and weeks of that war?

The film could have been a mere gory affair with over-the-top emotional button-pushing. Instead, it employs astounding restraint - where shock and horror does occur, it serves as an absolutely essential part of the narrative and character development.

That narrative is ambitious: it manages to tackle subjects as difficult and complex as xenophobia, misguided and/or uninformed kinds of patriotism, prejudice, white-washing of history… Even if all of the POWs had been fully brainwashed and indoctrinated boys (they are not), it is impossible not to empathise with them.

The contrast between "if they are old enough to go to war then they are old enough to clean up the mess" and "they are just little boys crying for their mother" could have been presented in a hugely manufactured manner, but the film manages to hammer it home with remarkable economy and restraint.

On top of all this, it also presents us with a staggering personal journey: that of the Danish officer in charge of the boys, who genuinely transforms himself from a resentful, hate-filled individual into someone who makes a personal sacrifice, with consequences we can only guess, to save at least some of the boys. Similarly, a local mother and her little daughter manage to convey a universal story about prejudice and what it can change into. A dropped basket of bread tells in a split second more than many pages and minutes of overworked script could do.

Visually, the use of the colours and the vistas of the coastline give the film a mesmerising look. It is a Universe of subdued colours, with abstract patterns of the flag-marked minefield. The clashing and constantly changing elements of nature remind us of how Tarkovsky underpinned his story with those elements in Ivan's Childhood.

The acting is stunning, it goes from restrained minimalism to visceral explosions of emotions. The editing, the camera work, the framing are superb. We go from vast vistas to Sergio Leone-style close-ups with a pair of eyes that can tell pages and pages of stories, we go from pure poetry to naturalistic (but utterly functional and not overdone) depictions of absolute horror.

Louis Hofmann as the boy who becomes the leader of the group delivers a performance of an intensity we know him for by now (see the Netflix series Dark and other German films, too). The Belton twins are astounding, they age decades in seconds, in front of our eyes.

The lead role from Moller, who plays the sergeant in charge of the boys, is also spellbinding. Under his stoic surface there is absolute and unconditional hate, which develops into selfless empathy by the end of the film. The inner journey is not linear and not simple - and he is initially downright angry with himself when he notices the first signs of compassion in himself.

The final lines in the film put the events in a numeric context… and the numbers are horrific.

However, at a personal level, in the micro-Universe of those few lads on that vast beach, the central stories of this film, too are universal. Again, they transcend specific ideologies and historical framing…

Land of Mine is about people being able not only to overcome their mental conditioning in the most inhumane circumstances even, but also to elevate themselves to the level of almost self-destructive altruism.

"Land of mine" is a great movie which plays with the viewer on psychological level. It assumes that you have already seen all the atrocities that Nazi soldiers did during WWII and it makes you feel sad for people, that did all of that. It makes you understand, what the Allies felt after defeating the Nazis. The movie has so much suspense and tension, which I haven't seen in a foreign language film for years. It puts you in front of a Batman-like dilemma, that sergeant Rasmussen is facing, which is "Are we really better than them if we treat them like they treated us?". He is always trying to get rid of this thought throughout the entire movie, but he can't. Because all of us are humans and all of us have feelings. This movie is brilliant and deserves all the positive reviews that were made about it, as I have never thought I would actually cry because of a Nazi soldier's fate.
Well-acted, suspenseful and meaningful drama.

Though very cliched and unrealistic in its sergeant character, Land of Mine is otherwise unflinchingly raw and gruesome in its portrayal of war crimes as it deals with a lesser-known, but very important, tragic and horrific event in Danish history. The very intense tone throughout is the film's highlight.

The movie makes you sympathetic towards the young kids recruited as soldiers for Nazi Germany. I watched it during a flight from Germany to India. Even from small screen it sent me through a jorney of dispair and hopelesness. Beautifully made.
This is one powerful film. Unforgettable.
Horrifying and impactful.
A tense little war film

"Land of Mine" is a beautifully shot war drama, that teaches us that a war does not actually end on the day written on  history books. Winners and losers end up being victims of a game so much bigger than them, and this film focuses on a particular chapter that take place after the fight, but way before the healing of the characters involved. Very good and touching.
kept me on the edge of my seat knowing the danger these boys felt.  A bit predictable but a story about how humans are humans and boys are boys

This Danish contender for Oscar Best Foreign Language Film shares the neglected annals of teenage German POWs coerced to clear mine fields with a heart-wrenching story of a Danish sergeant's experiencing a change of heart when he realises his juvenile captives are no more than casualties of World War II like himself.
Love this movie, especially the original score. Amazing.

Land of mine (under sandet), is a modern, brutal and complex war story driven by hate and relations. It is not scared to be harsh, and try to depict the essence of tension in its time. The movie mostly succeeds at this with a constant action combined with emotions, in a experience of only just long enough to be a feature film.
History in film is great if accurate. This is the case. Very realistic, we feel the danger. Still, I have no pity for the germans though.

Great drama. 

May 1945 and the war in Europe has ended.  German soldiers are put to work on the Danish coast, clearing mines buried on the beaches.  It is a dangerous job and the Germans are young and inexperienced.  One such unit is supervised by Sergeant Rasmussen, a veteran of the war and someone who hates the Germans and what they did to his country during the war.  He takes his anger out on the young boys in his unit.  However, over time his attitude changes.

Great drama.  Deals with aspects of war that are hardly ever dealt with - what happens after the war ends, how former enemies now have to live with each other and how the victors treat the vanquished.  The attitude towards and treatment of the Germans by the Danes is quite understandable and plausible.  This makes the reconciliation so much more emotional.

Quite gritty - the dangers the German soldiers are exposed to are highlighted very well.   These dangers also up the tension, making for riveting viewing at times.

Not perfect though.  Some of the transformations seem too simple and quick and the conclusion feels a touch too neat.  It would also have been good to see some of the characters' histories, especially the Sergeant's, to provide a bit more character depth and engagement.  Not essential though, as one can easily imagine how he got to be that way.

Ultimately, a great story of reconciliation.

At the end of World War Two, the Danish military used 2000 German POWs, most of whom were still teenagers to clear land mines laid by the Nazis along the Danish coast as they believed this to be the original planned landing spot for the Allied invasion. This story follows 14 of these young men as they are assigned to the command of a Danish sergeant to clear one area of beach along the coastline of Denmark, afterwards they are promised they will be allowed to return to Germany.
The Danish sergeant at first resents his role and has a strong hatred of the Germans.  It's only after he has spent time working with these boys that he grows to respect them and feel sympathy for these young men who just want to return home to their families.
It was a very well acted film and as you can imagine, extremely tense during the numerous scenes of bomb disposal.  By the end of the film, the viewers' sympathies do lie with the German soldiers, who having experienced the horrors of war were now facing another fight for survival on the beaches of Denmark.
Wow! Excellent film all around.
Compelling, heart-breaking and effective.
Tense, heartbreaking, and educational.
Good movie but all in closed captions.

This Danish/German co-production, focuses on the German WWII prisoners of war, tasked with clearing mines from the Danish beaches, following the conclusion of said conflict. Usually just teenagers, with no actual war-experience, thousands died after being forced to clear the coast-lines by hand, inch by inch, all the while being starved and humiliated by their captors.

The brilliance of Martin Zandvliet's film lies with the performances. The young German soldiers are all uniformly brilliant, but it is Roland Møller who steals the show, as gruff sergeant Carl Rasmussen, the war-weary, battle-scarred combatant assigned to their unit, charged with escorting the recruits to the beaches and motivating them into clearing the mines. His character has a unique arc, in that he swings from loathing his young squad, to almost becoming a father-figure to them at times, but throughout there are surprising twists and turns, that compels the audience to hate him one minute, then love him the next.

The tension is another key element of the film's success. An early training scene, where the prisoners are being schooled on how to disassemble the different variants of mines, is beautifully written and directed and showcases this taut atmosphere that prevails throughout. It also highlights the festering hatred that was prevalent immediately following the war's conclusion, and how the emotion throughout the affected countries, could lead even apposite people to question their own basic human decency.
Constant tension and danger makes it difficult to watch but an important story to tell.

An emotionally gripping tale well told. . .well acted. . .well filmed. The price of the aftermath of war and the toll it took on captured enemy soldiers as well as victors- those assigned to supervise them & bitter residents.  "Somebody had to do it". . .brings to mind all the countries with buried leftover land mines with no such organized plan to clear land mines.
That's left to poor children younger than those depicted here.  Gives another, much crueler meaning to "the spoils of war".

The greatest thing about this movie is that there is no black and no white ... only varying shades of gray. It effortlessly mixes hatred, criminality, compassion, and redemption. The characters are all sharply drawn, and the acting is sensational. Moller, of course, is a veritable maelstrom as Carl Rasmussen, the career soldier who makes his own journey throughout the film. As a fluent German speaker, I didn't need the subtitles, but when I watched it again, I checked the translations. They are uniformly excellent. This film is powerful, deeply disturbing, and utterly unafraid to ask tough questions for which there are no simple answers. See it. Heck, see it twice. It's worth it.

Gripping story of teenage German POWs clearing mines from a  Danish beach, doesn't pull any punches with the danger and realities of what they were doing.  Plenty of resentment and hatred toward these boys of course with a sprinkling of forgiveness as well.  Not precisely a "war' film but anyone who likes the genre should give it a watch.

Land of mine is a great foreign film that shows a part of war that is often not represented in movies and even in the history books we read. This film uses fear, anger, and love to build a story worth watching.

A refreshing title in an over polluted ocean of war or post war movies. The tension built through out this film reminds us of a wound so often forgotten in the film or even video game industry: Post war hazards. Even today, we have organizations that are dedicated to clearing ancient mine fields. Vietnam, many areas of Europe, and even the Middle East. This film uses a fantastic sound scape to set the mood, and help build the tension. It forces us to tackle had topics, and teaches that hate only further fuels hate. We are shown compassion, frustration, fear, and love all in one film. Coupled with a well built cast, this uses history to continue teaching us lessons. I give this film a high recommendation, and happily place it in my list of favorites.

Land of Mine is an eye opening dramatization of one of the least known chapters of World War Two, in which German POWs, many still in their teens, were forced to clear millions of landmines from the Danish coast immediately after the war's end. Befitting its subject it's a well-crafted suspense drama, but more than that it's a masterful and deeply engaging work of emotional and moral nuance. It's not every war movie that can make viewers sympathize with the Germans.

Looking back, we like to think of WWII as a good war, a triumph of good over evil. And not without reason. The Allied Powers saved Europe from the genocidal Nazi regime and Asia from the brutality of Imperial Japan. But no war is won without morally questionable acts. And forcing these men to clear millions of landmines was even more questionable because the war had already been won. Using the enemy to clear the mines their comrades had laid may have seemed an expedient solution, yet it smacks of vindictiveness and one can't shake the feeling that what we're seeing amount to a war crime.

It's the deep ethical questions and personal drama that give the film its depth, but it's the suspense that holds the viewers' attention. We know that at any moment the slightest mistake could end one of these boys' lives. And of course it does, more than once. We dread the moment when the next boy will die, and it' absolutely devastating when it happens. Yet the movie never becomes too mournful, or lingers too long. Soon enough the tone is again tense, or hopeful, or occasionally even humorous.

Just as the film- and the boys'- mood has its ups and downs, so does their relationship with the Danish sergeant placed in command of them (Roland Møller). It's naturally antagonistic at first. These Germans were members of the Nazi army occupying his country, and he is their jailer as much as their commander. He tells them repeatedly that he does not care if they are miserable or if they die, as long as the mines are cleared. And he means it, mostly.

 It's equally natural that his stance towards them will soften as he comes to see them as people rather than enemies. But this change is not inevitable or without stumbles. At one point he becomes so callous that one almost fears he will become the villain of his own story. It's fascinating watching his conflicting emotions, his struggle to balance his duty with his humanity.

The result is a deeply poignant, intimate, and earnest film that reminds us that even our enemies are human and even the most seemingly clear cut conflicts aren't always as black and white as we would like to think. There are no easy answers or sense of closure here, but then the men involved never received any either.
A good exploration into two of the worst legacies of war, land mines and hatred.

Just a great movie.  It is so heartbreaking but the acting is exceptional.  Everyone is perfect for their role.  Will try and find a copy of this to keep for my self.  But it will break your heart.  This is true story, over half of these German teenagers used by Denmark died and it is considered the worse war crime Denmark committed.
A story you never heard. Heartbreaking.

Silent yet deeply efficacious, 
Traumatising yet immensely ebullient, 
Horrifying yet endlessly substantial, this unearthly true tale of World War aftermath is European cinema at its finest peppering an literally explosive study of retribution, innocence, cruelty, humiliation, compassion and rediscovering humanity

Both Møller and Zandvliet prove capable in their exploration of war, compassion and humanity. Land of Mine would prove a gripping watch to any viewer but is timed well for genre fans aching for new layers.
Really good, very tense moments throughout the whole movie and also interesting historically. I feel bad for those soldiers though I got to say...

Violence and War.... and then juveniles with seasoned army officers. War and death are great equalizers, all appear the same in the end- dead. This is a very subtlety acted movie despite the fact there is no need for it, for the stark landscape and the act of clearing mines on a vast empty beach is enough drama any cinematic canvas can hold.
It underlines what we all forget, overlook even in daily lives.
The reality of humans coming in contact with one another and lives being changed forever. 
A post WWII drama with none of the clichés usually associated with the genre. Kindness and forgiveness... all that is truly left in the end to do if we are to remain human.
I could not go to sleep after watching this movie. Beautiful, powerful and absolutely horrifying.
heartbreaking. excellent acting. highly recommend.
Excellent.  I had no idea about this history.
Good flick. Once foes, and no longer at war, they now need to confront humanity. Do you remain enemies or are you able to move on.

Beautiful movie that keeps the audience watching and waiting for the next  horrific event to occur to one of the many characters we come to love throughout the film. Graphic and unforgiving to the core, everyone needs to see this movie.
This film is full of tension; don't be alarmed if you find yourself feeling sorry for these German youth after watching this.

One of the best movies!!!

I don't know if it was intentional, but none of the characters really resonated as someone to care about.  The story was still entertaining though.

Gripping, essential film that deals wonderfully with the brutality of war. Set in Denmark at the end of the Second World War we follow young German prisoners of war that are ordered to remove landmines from the Danish coastline. This film is superbly acted and expertly maintains tension and drama through out. There is redemption and pathos on show with great effect, resulting in a work of great art and tremendous heart.

Tells the story of requirements of German soldiers in one nation invaded by the Nazis in WWII.  

Causes audiences to think about some moral issues.  

But mostly all I could think of while watching this movie is that "War is hell."
The expected clichés could not be avoided.  There are good production values and the director brings out fine performances from the actors working through a familiar plot.

A story of perpetual struggle and emotional hardship, Land Of Mine, a refreshingly clever title pun, documents the exploits of an oft-forgotten group of German World War 2 soldiers. Forced to clear the mines their own countrymen had planted along the Danish coast, while also facing up to the prejudice of those who previous fought against them, the movie does a stellar job of not only getting us to sympathise with the prisoners of war, but also care for them. Many of the mine disarming scenes are close to nail-biting, and whenever one of them goes off it's a genuine shocker, especially in the excellent training phase sequence. The Danish superiors often come across as one-dimensional villains with no redeeming values, with Roland Møller's resentful Sergeant being the only one which gets any development or moments of genuine humanity, but it's the only significant weakness I believe the film possesses. It's hard to believe the depicted events were condoned, considering that the young soldiers forced to clear the mines were conscripted at the tail end of the war, and as such had little chance to participate in any important battles. But the film demonstrates how prejudice can often be the most blinding feeling we have, particularly in a time of conflict. Frank, hard-hitting and illuminating, Land Of Mine is a war film which will likely never get the credit or attention it deserves, but if anything, that's even more of a reason to watch it.

Land of Mine: More than 2000 German POWs were forced to clear nearly two million landmines from the beaches of Denmark following WWII. Most were teenagers and most died or were horribly maimed in the process. This gut-wrenching, 2017 Oscar nominee for Best Foreign Language Film is the story about a group of them. It is a film of juxtaposition - virtual children performing adult tasks, shockingly grisly deaths on a beautiful beach, and one-time oppressors who now are the oppressed. While the harrowing story is emotionally akin to two nerve-racking hours of Russian roulette, it is so exquisitely done with such powerful performances and a haunting score that it should be seen by everyone... but probably only once. A
Tense and riveting. A surprisingly good film about a terrible situation.

The film is gripping and tense enough to compensate for the main character's problems in characterization - especially his abrupt change in behavior towards the German boys, which comes off as forced and heavy-handed -, and it also benefits from a strong ending.

Knowing that the key elements in this film will consist of German teenager POWs being forced to clear landmines, the brutal consequences are inevitable and there can be no mystery about what awful scenes it must contain.  Its point is simple: this is no way to treat children regardless of how Hitler's Germany used them, or what they did in the war.  It depicts the vengeful Allies as little better than the enemy, when they are subjecting the boys to inhuman labour, starvation, beatings and humiliation.  Bridging the two worlds is the boys' commandant, a Danish sergeant who carries out his orders, but with degrees of compassion. The film begs the questions: what is the right punishment for an oppressor and how far down into the population should it have extended; at what point is following orders a defence to war crimes; how were these boys recruited or conscripted; what would these boys have become, if Nazi Germany had prevailed; what do they symbolise now.  And, if the method of clearing the mines was the forced labour of the enemy, in the form of half-starved, sick, scared and degraded teenagers, what guarantee is there even now that the beaches and the other minefields of Europe are safe?  The film's ending, while appropriate to the story, leaves the questions open. The Danish sergeant's way is to understand the past, and then to lock it away, never to be repeated, but the unknown factor is how many agree with him - then, or now.
It was a good reminder of events and the joy brought to many
Insightful and thoughtful character- development makes this film exceptional, possibly even unique

Solid story, pretty different war film, or post war film. Exciting all the way, as you can expect when the plot basicly is land mine clearing in Denmark. It's done by German soliders. Young ones, probably war prisoners or something. They are not very popular fellas so people never care about their very dangerous work. They don't care if most of them die, they only want it done.

Great location, lovely visuals and some nice editing. Very solid acting once again from Roland Møller. He's becoming one of my Danish favorites, really.

It's a bit predictable, that kills a bit of the vibe, but not too much. In total it's a very solid historical drama. "Krigen", another Danish war film done the same year was another very solid film. Very different as they were sat 70 years apart or so, but the race between the two of being the best film is darn close for me.

7 out of 10 beetles.
Very good movie with an emotional story to tell.

An intensely emotional and human film, that tackles the subject of a man's uniform and what's under it very delicately and in the way it should be. The film suffers a bit of predictability and it could have used a longer running time: it would have helped unfold the story and develop character relationships even further. These minor problems aside Land of Mine is an astounding and beautifully shot film.
Mel Gibson, top of his game.
A beautifully crafted film; heart-wrenching, heart-warming. Hard to watch but worth it.

Land of Mine is a refreshingly original and compelling post-war picture.  As a result of the director filming much of the movie during the day's Golden Hour, the film vividly presents a striking portraiture of serenity and beauty periodically shattered by horrific explosions.
must watch for WWII fans
Little know story, in the aftermath of WW2. Very moving story of vengeance and forgiveness. Two thumbs way up!
Magnificent masterpiece. A must see on a big screen if possible. Extraordinary in every way.
A Riveting Film Great Acting/characters/old-school cinematography!

'Land of Mine' is a 2015 Danish-German historical drama war film which was selected and nominated for the Best Foreign Language Film category at the 89th Academy Awards.  The film is inspired by real events and tells the story of German prisoners of war sent to clear land mines in Denmark after World War II.

Powerful, tense, and sobering, this is a really good movie and a tough watch.  You're never quite certain when something bad will happen and when you are lulled into a false sense of security: BANG.   Well acted and despite a script that is a bit predictable which kept it from being a great movie this is definitely one you want to see if you're not afraid of films with subtitles.  It's also an important reminder of what war does for both the winners and losers.  Final Score: 8.6/10

Relentless sadism with about 5 minutes of redeeming script. The Danes mounted no great resistance to the WWII German occupation until it was clear that the tide had turned and the Germans were going to lose. As a result, Denmark had a low number of war casualties compared to other European countries (just 16 Danish soldiers had died in the invasion). At the end of the war, by which time the German army had been turned into a tragic children's crusade, the Danes forced thousands of POWs, many of them teenagers, to disarm land mines, with predictable results. (One wonders why this practice wasn't against the Geneva Convention.) I bailed on this film after 30 minutes; my husband stuck it out and wished he hadn't. A terrible, terrible, terrible film. The Danes come off badly. The sadistic sergeant I wanted dead in the first 5 minutes. He survives, but his final act proves too little and too late for redemption.
Heavy.   How were the Danish different from the Nazis if German innocent soldiers were forced to bear the punishment for their country?

Great film about a little known chapter of post-World War II Europe. It's beautifully photographed with outstanding performances from Roland Moller as a Danish Sergeant charged with overseeing the clearing of land mines from a Danish beach as well as from the ensemble portraying young captured German soldiers.  Director Martin Zandvliet takes us on a harrowing journey of war and retribution. Highly recommend.

It may be difficult to watch due to the subject, but there's no denying that Land Of Mine is one of the most intriguing and suspenseful films inspired by a true story I've seen in 2017, and it's one of the better films to come out this year as well.

4 1/2 Stars. This film captures humanity at it's absolute best and most raw. It truly captures something wonderful, I feel. It shows how truly ugly nationalism is from whatever side you're on and that we're all humans on a floating rock in space and we're all in this together. This is exactly the kind of film that needs to be seen these days. Glad we're getting more and more of them. The only fault of the film is the familiar beats it follows. Definitely doesn't try to reinvent storytelling but it got the story that needed to be told out there the best it could. Humanist filmmaking at it's best.

Spoiler alert: this review contains spoilers!
The topic of this movie makes it surely a serious one, you can be sure about it. Unfortunately for the movie, one of the most intense and dramatic scenes, when the dog jumps on a mine and explodes, is filmed in a way so comic that is impossible not to explode (lol) in fat and loud laughs. Seriously, is there a possible way in which a dog jumping on a mine while trying to catch a ball, can be filmed without making everyone starting to laugh? I strongly doubt it, but maybe is just my opinion.
Hard to watch at times, brutal, and thought provoking too.  This film shows the dangers of landmines and how costly war can be.
The fog of war takes time to clear.  This movie show that but give a hopeful message that the fog can clear with the help of getting to know our enemies as people.

A very scary film.  Also a film that educates you about a time of post war Denmark with a lot of heart.  Also a very scary film.  Did I mention that it will scare you?  I should have, as it is a very scary film. CDW

European quality movie, outstanding production of a story about German boys who are labeled nazis and enemies just because they were happened to be born in Germany and the whole world unleashes its hatred upon them. DAS HURT LOCKER - My Review of LAND OF MINE (3 Stars)

One of this year's Academy Award nominated Foreign Language films has repurposed its title for certain audiences and it has left me baffled. Originally called UNDER SANDET (translation: UNDER THE SAND), the story of post WW2 German soldiers held as prisoners of war until they can clear the mines they had planted along Denmark's west coast, the U.S. version bears the title: LAND OF MINE. Seriously? That's the sort of bad pun my readers have come to expect from my review titles, but its use here undermines a serious yet flawed piece of filmmaking.

Writer/Director Martin Zandvliet, along with his cinematographer Camilla Hjelm bring a sweeping, widescreen beauty to this harrowing, deeply felt, excruciating story. On a remote, sandy coastline, Danish Sgt. Sgt. Carl Rasmussen (a very good Roland Møller), oversees a small troupe of mostly Aryan teenage prisoners. He brutalizes and starves them while demanding they work faster and faster to defuse the mines. His lack of warmth feels appropriate considering the horrors the Nazis brought to his homeland, but the film keeps reminding us of the prisoners' innocence, or at the very least, their lack of ideology. More on that later.

For much of the running time, we helplessly watch, knowing that at any moment a mine will surely explode. Think of it as THE HURT LOCKER with lesser technology and more blonde hair. Taking a page from Alfred Hitchcock's manual of suspense, Zandvliet builds intense dread as these kids crawl along the beach poking beneath the sand with sticks. Because we know what lies beneath, it's impossible not to watch this film with at least one hand covering your face. I almost walked out during several key moments, unsure that I could take it anymore. The seriousness of the subject matter and the fine performances all around, however, convinced me to stay. But man is it rough to watch a bomb tear apart a person.

In one scene, Rasmussen slaps the shit out of one of the kids, who seems to simultaneously laugh and cry over his beating. In others, the sergeant acts very tenderly towards his charges. He even laughs when one of the soldiers, in a very movie star quality performance by Louis Hofmann, fakes him out with a bomb noise, which seems wildly inappropriate, but #gallowshumor, right? Rasmussen's mixed feelings echo the themes of the film. How can we reconcile our warm feelings for these kids knowing what their fellow soldiers, or perhaps even they themselves, did during the war?

Unfortunately, Zandvliet eschews this political conundrum in favor of the sentimental "people are people" theme. I kept thinking how much richer this film would have been if some of the kids still espoused anti-semitic feelings or if we learned that some had committed crimes against humanity. Instead, we learn of their post-war hopes and dreams of rebuilding Germany and getting on with their lives. We delight in their playing soccer on the beach and we sympathize with them when they go without food. This lack of complexity prevents the film from truly soaring to another level.

It's fine, suspenseful, gut-wrenching filmmaking, but its point of view left me confused. Yes, it's entirely possible that many German soldiers had little choice but to serve. I understand how under Hitler's dictatorship, the citizens had to follow orders, but his ascendancy came from a groundswell of public sentiment. Hell, half of our own country supports the actions of a President the other half despises, and yet we're all responsible, in a way, for his rise to power.


In one particularly, harsh scene, a group of British soldiers beat up and urinate all over one of the prisoners. He takes the humiliation, we're led to think, in the manner of Jesus dying for our sins. He gets it. The Nazis sucked. They had it coming. LAND OF MINE, however, hedges its bets by wanting us to forget about such vengeful feelings and hope that acts of kindness lay the groundwork for a better future. A wonderful thought, if only life were so simple. This good film could have achieved greatness had it given us that extra layer of painting one or two of its prisoners as Nazi sympathizers. Still, this missed opportunity merits a look, a cowered look, but a look nonetheless.

Movies about World War II are pretty much a genre in and of themselves now, so filmmakers have got to find largely unknown stories to tell in order to make something interesting. Land of Mine--which has the Danish title Under sandet, translating to the far less punny Under the Sand--works generally well thanks to its solid storytelling and strong filmmaking. There are stretches in which the script treats the characters are more of an amorphous collective than individuals, and although the intentions are understandable, it undercuts some emotional ties, but the movie still has quiet tension about it with strong acting. The movie tells the true story of a group of German prisoners of war in 1945 who, directly after the end of World War II, are sent to defuse and remove thousands of landmines scattered across the beaches of west Denmark while under the watch of a Danish sergeant. What makes the movie have of air of uniqueness is that it's generally quiet, letting the tension lie quietly below the surface, capable of going off at almost any moment. Writer/director Martin Zandvliet spends much of the film's 100 minutes on engrossing the audience in the landscapes of the movie, with establishing shots that are as peaceful as they are cold. Music isn't used much, letting diegetic ambience create most of the movie's mood. The actors are all on similar planes in terms of believability but vary in delivery in ways fitting to their respective characters. Whereas the positives in Land of Mine seemed to have come to fruition in the production and post-production stages, the Zandvliet's writing isn't quite as satisfying. Now there are moments where the underwhelming nature is warranted and adds to the movie, but the first half isn't as good as the second in that these characters are generally indistinguishable from each other. The intention of making their humanity shine through more and more over the course of the film is apparent, but we don't know much of anything about these guys in the beginning. Their prisoners of war and therefore one would expect more depth to them off the bat, but here they don't become more of their own people until after the midpoint. Dynamics grow and stakes feel higher later on, but my interest in these characters was strained at times in the first half, and I was left with the performances to be as engaged as I was. Nonetheless, Land of Mine is careful in its portrayal of war--or post-war--violence in that it never fetishizes the physical of emotional torment of those onscreen, instead treating it as a period to the run-on sentences that these characters' lives have become. There's a sense of endlessness that the movie wears well. Script choices are understandable but unhelpful in the first half, fighting the movie's depth by insisting that the characters be portrayed in knee-high storytelling, but when the audience is submerged, the movie becomes more engaging, even though it won't warrant heavy discussion or another viewing. 7.4/10, pretty good, B, above average, etc.

This was like another 'Kajaki', but not actually a war film. Using of the prisoners as the labourers is a violation, according to the Geneva rule. Just when you thought we've exhausted all fresh ideas for a film about WWII along comes this incredibly affecting Danish film about young German POWs clearing German-laid mines on the west coast of Denmark, based on a bit of history that's little known even in Denmark.  Thoughtful and stunning camera work sets their bleak tasks against the beauty that is the cold sandy white beaches there. The amazing cast of unknowns means that anyone can be casualty anytime thus further escalating the tension in an already unbearable intense film. One can criticize the ending but, without spoiling it, it is one that is not only earned (as part of the main character's arc) but also necessary in such a sombre yet humanizing film. Emitting a relentless aura of erratic danger, 'Land of Mine' emotionally drains you halfway through before further pummeling your will to watch all the way past the swift 100-minute runtime. Writer/Director Martin Zandvliet conceives a drab, shocking, and morally perplexing study of post-war German realism through a dozen young German POWs forced to defuse thousands of Nazi landmines under the guidance of the strict and patriotic Sgt. Carl (Roland Moller). The film is an intelligent allegory of WW2's affect on the future of Germany, but rarely does 'Land of Mine' cease its looming anxiety in favor of its purpose, only slowing down to allow audiences a breather. Naturally, however, with a land full of mines one can never get too comfortable.
